title: Azure
text: Ensure connected required VPNs Run setupAzureCreds(). ’ll prompted enter server, database, username password. securely stored operating system’s credential manager. update credentials use updateAzureCreds(). prompt fields change.
code: library(unifrog) #> Default ggplot theme set to unifrog_theme(). Unifrog colour palettes applied.

title: Azure
text: getAzureResults() function able query database, long connected VPN. raw .sqlquery must first formatted using helper functions glue readr example , query_results.csv already exists query executed. Instead, .csv file read using readr::read_csv() default behaviour can overridden , example, data query changed using overwrite = TRUE argument.
code: library(readr) query_text <- read_file("query_name.sql") query_text #> [1] "SELECT TOP(20) student_keyno, student_year_of_graduation\r\nFROM student\r\n" require(glue) #> Loading required package: glue library(glue) query <- glue_sql(query_text) query #> <SQL> SELECT TOP(20) student_keyno, student_year_of_graduation #> FROM student results <- getAzureResults(SQLscript = query,                            output = "query_results.csv") results #> # A tibble: 20 × 2 #>    student_keyno student_year_of_graduation #>            <dbl>                      <dbl> #>  1        158341                       2017 #>  2        158342                       2017 #>  3        158343                       2017 #>  4        158344                       2019 #>  5        158345                       2017 #>  6        158346                       2017 #>  7        158347                       2020 #>  8        158348                       2017 #>  9        158349                       2017 #> 10        158350                       2017 #> 11        158351                       2018 #> 12        158352                       2017 #> 13        158353                       2017 #> 14        158354                       2017 #> 15        158355                       2017 #> 16        158356                       2017 #> 17        158357                       2018 #> 18        158358                       2019 #> 19        158359                       2021 #> 20        158360                       2017 results <- getAzureResults(SQLscript = query,                            output = "query_results.csv",                            overwrite = TRUE) results #>    student_keyno student_year_of_graduation #> 1         158341                       2017 #> 2         158342                       2017 #> 3         158343                       2017 #> 4         158344                       2019 #> 5         158345                       2017 #> 6         158346                       2017 #> 7         158347                       2020 #> 8         158348                       2017 #> 9         158349                       2017 #> 10        158350                       2017 #> 11        158351                       2018 #> 12        158352                       2017 #> 13        158353                       2017 #> 14        158354                       2017 #> 15        158355                       2017 #> 16        158356                       2017 #> 17        158357                       2018 #> 18        158358                       2019 #> 19        158359                       2021 #> 20        158360                       2017

title: Palettes
text: extracts unifrog palette colours hex codes. Examples .
code: unifrog_colors() #>        red     orange     yellow       grey   darkgrey  lightblue       blue  #>  "#a50036"  "#ff7901"  "#c89801"  "#cccccc"  "#8c8c8c"  "#17a0ff"  "#1561c8"  #>      green     purple      brown       pink background       main  #>  "#33cc99"  "#6815ad"  "#b54f0d"  "#ec44f2"  "#FFFFFF"  "#000000" unifrog_colors("green", "lightblue", "darkgrey") #>     green lightblue  darkgrey  #> "#33cc99" "#17a0ff" "#8c8c8c"

title: Palettes
text: can view palettes pretty way using unikn package     grouped three categories: Discrete - ‘unifrog_main’ Sequential - ‘unifrog_blues’, ‘unifrog_greens’, ‘unifrog_oranges’, ‘unifrog_reds’ Diverging - ‘likert3’, ‘likert5’, ‘likert7’
code: library(unikn) #> Welcome to unikn (v0.8.0)! #> seecol() shows colors or color palettes. seecol(unifrog_colors(), main = "The entire Unifrog colour scheme") seecol(unifrog_main, main = "The \"main\" palette is default for discrete data") seecol(likert3, main = "The \"likert3\" palette is default for continuous data") seecol(unifrog_palettes,        main = "The names of all of the Unifrog palettes",        pal_names = names(unifrog_palettes))

title: Palettes
text: fill specified, categorical variable, default scale_fill_unifrog_d("unifrog_main").  can see addition line 4 effect output  Addition reverse = TRUE line 4starts opposite end palette.  order guarantee colour reversal unifrog_main use fct_rev fill argument.  want use different palette, can specify palette argument. Note sequential palette often make sense bar charts.
code: ggplot(iris, aes(x = Species, y = Sepal.Length, fill = Species)) +   geom_boxplot() +   theme_classic() ggplot(iris, aes(x = Species, y = Sepal.Length, fill = Species)) +   geom_boxplot() +   theme_classic() +   scale_fill_unifrog_d() ggplot(iris, aes(x = Species, y = Sepal.Length, fill = Species)) +   geom_boxplot() +   theme_classic() +   scale_fill_unifrog_d(reverse = TRUE) ggplot(iris, aes(x = Species, y = Sepal.Length, fill = fct_rev(Species))) +   geom_boxplot() +   theme_classic() +   scale_fill_unifrog_d() ggplot(iris, aes(x = Species, y = Sepal.Length, fill = Species)) +   geom_violin() +   scale_fill_unifrog_d(palette = "unifrog_greens") +   theme_classic()

title: Palettes
text: continuous variables, default scale_fill_unifrog_c("likert3")  can change way shown using color aesthetic.
code: ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy, color = hwy)) +   geom_point() +   theme_bw() ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy, color = hwy)) +   geom_point() +   scale_color_unifrog_c('likert5') +   theme_bw()

title: Unifrog Data Team Helpers
text: goal provide set function help production documents reproducible research Unifrog House Style. contains main part: Functions interaction Azure database, including secure way store credentials using keyring package. corporate ggplot2 theme Unifrog - unifrog_theme() Corporate colour palettes including discrete, sequential diverging versions.

what: Connect to the Azure Database and Run a Query — getAzureResults
title: Connect to the Azure Database and Run a Query — getAzureResults
text: overwrite = FALSE output file already exists, database queried csv read instead.

title: Connect to the Azure Database and Run a Query — getAzureResults
Connect to the Azure Database and Run a Query — getAzureResults
text: SQLscript glue object containing SQL script (glue_sql()) output string containing path csv output overwrite logical indicating whether output csv overwritten. Defaults FALSE.

title: Connect to the Azure Database and Run a Query — getAzureResults
Unifrog likert3 palette — likert3
code: library(unikn) #> Welcome to unikn (v0.8.0)! #> ac() adjusts color transparency. seecol(likert3, main = "likert3")

title: Unifrog colour palette — palette_unifrog
text: palette based colours Unifrog tools shown tool.tool_hex Azure.

title: Unifrog colour palette — palette_unifrog
text: palette Character name palette. Depending color scale, can `"main"` (default, discrete), `"likert3"`, `"likert5"`, `"likert7"` diverging scales. reverse Boolean indicating whether palette reversed. ... Additional arguments pass [`colorRampPalette()`][colorRampPalette].

title: Unifrog colour palette — scale_color_unifrog
text: palette based colours Unifrog tools shown tool.tool_hex Azure. Use `scale_color_unifrog_d` *discrete* categories `scale_color_unifrog_c` *continuous* scale.

title: Unifrog colour palette — scale_color_unifrog
code: scale_color_unifrog(   palette = "unifrog_main",   discrete = TRUE,   reverse = FALSE,   aesthetics = "color",   ... )  scale_color_unifrog_d(   palette = "unifrog_main",   discrete = TRUE,   reverse = FALSE,   aesthetics = "color",   ... )  scale_color_unifrog_c(   palette = "likert3",   discrete = FALSE,   reverse = FALSE,   aesthetics = "color",   ... )  scale_colour_unifrog(   palette = "unifrog_main",   discrete = TRUE,   reverse = FALSE,   aesthetics = "color",   ... )  scale_colour_unifrog_c(   palette = "likert3",   discrete = FALSE,   reverse = FALSE,   aesthetics = "color",   ... )  scale_colour_unifrog_d(   palette = "unifrog_main",   discrete = TRUE,   reverse = FALSE,   aesthetics = "color",   ... )  scale_fill_unifrog(   palette = "unifrog_main",   discrete = TRUE,   reverse = FALSE,   aesthetics = "fill",   ... )  scale_fill_unifrog_d(   palette = "unifrog_main",   discrete = TRUE,   reverse = FALSE,   aesthetics = "fill",   ... )  scale_fill_unifrog_c(   palette = "likert3",   discrete = FALSE,   reverse = FALSE,   aesthetics = "fill",   ... )

title: Unifrog colour palette — scale_color_unifrog
text: palette Character name palette. Depending color scale, can `"main"` (default, discrete), `"likert3"`, `"likert5"`, `"likert7"` diverging scales. discrete Boolean indicating whether color aesthetic discrete . reverse Boolean indicating whether palette reversed. aesthetics vector names aesthetics scale applied (e.g., `c('color', 'fill')`). ... Additional arguments passed `discrete_scale()` `discrete` `TRUE` `scale_color_gradientn()` `discrete` `FALSE`.

title: Unifrog colour palette — scale_color_unifrog
code: library(ggplot2)  ggplot(iris, aes(x = Species, y = Sepal.Length, fill = Species)) +   geom_boxplot() +   scale_fill_unifrog_d() +   theme_bw()   ggplot(iris, aes(x = Species, y = Sepal.Length, fill = Species)) +   geom_violin() +   scale_fill_unifrog_d(palette = "likert3") +   theme_bw()   ggplot(iris, aes(x = Petal.Length, y = Petal.Width, color = Sepal.Length)) +   geom_point() +   scale_color_unifrog_c(palette = "likert7")+   theme_bw()
